text: hey everyone Thomas Joseph here now when
it comes to the holidays do you like to
make handmade gifts for your family and
friends well today I'm going to show you
how to make them a delicious gift and
that would be peanut brittle or any
other nut brittle it's surprisingly
simple to make and it shouldn't be
intimidating at all so let me show you
how I have a medium sauce pot here over
no heat one and a half cups of
granulated sugar 3/4 of a cup of water
and a half cup of corn syrup one trick
make sure you do it in one of these
glass measuring cups and give it a
little spray with some nonstick cooking
spray and it should slide right out of
the cup super easy and a generous pinch
of kosher salt so place this over
medium-high heat and bring this mixture
up to a boil now so our sugar mixture
has come up to a boil and now add a
candy thermometer and also at this point
if any crystals start forming around the
sides of the pan use one of these pastry
brushes and a little bit of water and
you can brush down any crystals that
form now the great thing about this
peanut brittle recipe is that it has
corn syrup which really does help in
preventing crystallization now we're
waiting for this mixture to come to 238
degrees Fahrenheit which is the soft
ball stage now crystallization if you're
not sure what I'm talking about
that is when little crystals kind of
almost like what you would see here with
these salt crystals form on the top of
your mixture and these sugar crystals
start building up and then they build up
even more and eventually you're left
with a pot of pure crystals so brushing
down with water really does help to
prevent the crystallization from forming
okay so our sugar syrup is up to 238
degrees which is softball and to
demonstrate what softball stage is I'm
going to take a little bit of our sugar
syrup and put it right into cold water
you only need a little bit and you
should be able to fish it out and
should be malleable when you squeeze it
and that means that it's a soft ball and
that means that you're ready for the
next step now the next step is adding
our peanuts I have two and a half cups
of dry roasted peanuts that are unsalted
and you could use dry roasted cashews
you could use dry roasted almonds any
nut even seeds really work well in
brittle so this goes right into the pot
so stir your peanuts in and now we need
to bring this up to hard crack stage and
just so I can stir the peanuts and I'm
gonna take this thermometer out just for
a second here give the mixture a good
stir it's already starting to change
colors and we want this to be a really
dark golden brown color we want to
develop the caramel so that it's not so
cleanly sweet it has a nice roasted
flavor to it and have on hand a 9 by 13
baking sheet that is buttered if you do
not stir the nut will start to burn and
brown on certain sides what you want to
do is constantly move the nuts around so
that they evenly toast and brown in your
caramel the mixture is seeming a little
bit more fluid now I'm going to return
my candy thermometer and this mixture
needs to come up to 300 to 310 degrees
now if you like a peanut brittle with
more in depth flavor go to the 310
degrees but if you'd like something
that's a little bit lighter you can go
to 300 so the peanut brittle is up to
300 degrees here I'm gonna turn the heat
off I'm going to add in a very important
ingredient and that is a teaspoon of
baking soda and you want to be careful
when you add the baking soda that you
stand back a little bit because it's
gonna bubble up in the pan and one
teaspoon of vanilla and baking soda is
what makes this a brittle because what
it does is it leavens your brittle and
it gives the brittle a little bit of an
airy lightness which is really great so
this mixture goes right on to that
baking sheet spread this out into a very
even layer using your offset spatula
that has been sprayed with nonstick
cooking spray and this ensures that it
will not stick to your special and
you'll get it into a
lare now be careful the pan itself is
very very hot so if you need a towel to
help you here do that but now this
mixture needs to cool completely before
we can crack it
so the peanut brittle has cooled
completely now if you buttered your pan
correctly it should pop out very easily
it gives the back of the tray a little
bit of a bend here and this you can tell
it's already released should come out in
one sheet just like this you can crack
it into whatever sizes you would like
now of course we're in the holiday
season here we're packing up peanut
brittle for gifting make sure that you
arrange them in a single layer and
divide them with parchment paper
otherwise they will have a tendency to
stick together so now that you have the
basic recipe you can customize that
however you would like enjoy guys and
Happy Holidays
you
